reviewText: I'm being honest when I say I really wanted to like this movie -- I really, really did -- especially with the magnificent cast! But ... I couldn't. Produced by Tom Hanks and Gary Goetzman, "Parkland" is based on the Vincent Bugliosi bookFour Days in November: The Assassination of President John F. Kennedy, which is an abridged version of Bugliosi's massive tomeReclaiming History: The Assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The only reason I gave this movie two stars was because of the performances -- all really well-done and believable (the scene of calling the time of death of the President is certainly one of the most heartwrenching moments I've seen in recent cinema). The story, on the other hand, is full of holes and inconsistencies. I understand what screenwriter/director Peter Landesman was trying to do: he was attempting to not tread on any "conspiracy" territory by not fully showing the Zapruder film and the headshot to the President's head; nor did he address the autopsy of the President and the controversy of that ordeal. Landesman probably wanted to simply make a film that stuck to the known, established facts of what happened that day in November rather than some fact that came out years later. The only problem with this approach is that there were events -- important ones -- that happened "that day" that were not included in the film at all, whether it was the major -- the most prominent being the President's autopsy, the findings of the bullet entry wounds, the gaping wound in the back of the President's head, or the testimony from several eyewitnesses that JFK's body was disturbed by being unwrapped somewhere between the departure of Parkland Hospital and the arrival in Washington; or the mundane -- Zapruder's receptionist Marilyn Sitzman, who was standing up on the concrete pedestal with Zapruder (because of Zapruder's vertigo) and not down on the ground, like she is portrayed in this film. But I guess Landesman doesn't have time to show any of these facts ... because he's too busy using up nearly five minutes or more simply showing the "honorable, brave, loyal" Secret Service agents making room for the President's casket on Air Force One -- a scene not important to the overall story unless you want to glorify an already known aspect of the Secret Service.If anything, this movie is a propaganda tool used at subliminally telling the public who watch it that if you believe Oswald worked for the CIA or did not shoot the President, then you must be a "crazy, deranged nut" just like Oswald's mother Marguerite (Jackie Weaver), or some cold, heartless, uptight bureaucrat just like Dallas County Coroner Earl Rose (Rory Cochran), are portrayed in this film. Landesman attempts to simply show the human side of the Kennedy assassination and how it affected the lives of various people that day; however, by not showing all of the facts, Landesman is doing a disservice to his story, the film, U.S. history and our country. The fact that Landesman left out several tidbits of eyewitness-proved events that day with those people with whom the film centers on, proves that this film is not accurate, which is OK if you know absolutely nothing about the JFK assassination. The problem with this is that people (especially young people) will watch this film and think every detail is absolute fact (a similar problem arose with the release of Oliver Stone'sJFK: Director's Cut (Two-Disc Special Edition)when it was released in 1991). Therefore, its attempt at being an accurate-yet-dramatic story is a failure. I'm not saying Landesman had to touch on "conspiracy theory" here, but he should have done what he set out to do: throw every true fact into his story as possible. That was simply not done. Need proof? Check out James DiEugenio'sReclaiming Parkland: Tom Hanks, Vincent Bugliosi, and the JFK Assassination in the New Hollywood.Some people may ask how do I know the eyewitness testimony of events that day (i.e. in the autopsy, etc.) are real and true. Well, ask yourself this: if one, two or three people -- with nothing to lose and no invested interest or employment with a "questioned authority" -- testify to an event and they all say the same thing, is it a concidence? Well, how about if 17 or 25 of these types of people say the same thing? Were all of these random people getting together and plotting on what they would tell investigators? I don't think so. If this movie were made even 20 years ago, I would be more keen to give it a higher rating because of the amount of information -- or lack thereof -- on the Kennedy assassination. But this film was released in 2013 -- after 50 years of investigation which have proven there was MUCH more to that day in Parkland than this movie reveals (Even Sylvia Meagher's 1966 bookAccessories After the Fact: The Warren Commission, the Authorities & the Report on the JFK Assassinationreveals more dramatic fact than this film). This is the antithesis to "JFK," showing the "Oswald-acted-alone" theory of the assassination. If "Parkland" succeeds at anything, it is for those who watch the movie to read these reviews and investigate for the missed facts, which did indeed happen and are not shown in this film. Read more, research, take in as much fact as possible and use common sense. Don't believe what any movie -- whether it's this one or "JFK" -- tells you just because it's what a majority say. It's up to you.

reviewText: PLOT POINTS REVEALED!.PARKLAND (2013) is an inside look at the JFK assassination that shows scenes and examines lives never before represented in a motion picture. It opens mere minutes before the Kennedy limo turns onto Elm St. We see Abe Zapruder (Paul Giamatti) and his secretary cross the street to a platform near the grassy knoll. Abe's viewpoint was 30 yards distant from where the kill shot got JFK. He was a wreck from this traumatic experience and never fully recovered. Referring to JFK, Zapruder told a persistent newspaperman that "his head just flew to pieces."Soon after, Zapruder's surrounded by agents, including the chief of Dallas Secret Service (Billy Bob Thornton) who flat out demands the film in his 8mm Bell & Howell camera, Instead, Abe and several agents went from lab to TV station trying to find someone to develop the film.Meanwhile, the dark blue limo has arrived at Parkland at 12:45 pm, five minutes after the shooting. We see JFK placed on a stretcher and whyeeled into an emergency room that immediately was overcrowded with doctors, nurses and JFK's entourage. Every step of their fruitless efforts to keep him alive is shown. Jackie wandewrs in, totally spattered with blood. She hands head nurse Marcia Gay Harden something. We're told it's a piece of skull and brains. Jackie moves to a corner, kneels and prays as last ditch heart massage is about to fail. The nurse goes to her locker and retrieves a large wooden crucifix. She hands it to Father Huber, who's administering last rites on the president's remains. He lays the cross on the chest. Later, after the interior of Air Force One is torn away to accomodate JFK's bronze casket, this crucifix is placed on it.The detail throughout is just remarkable.Perhaps the weirdest story is that of the Oswald family, brother Robert (James Badge Dale) and Lee's mom, Marguerite (Jacki Weaver). The old woman is clearly deranged, and not by this accusation against her son. Repeatedly she claims he's a CIA agent, when not demanding a payoff from LIFE magazine for her inside story. Robert is appalled, convinced his arrogant younger brother killed "the most important man in the world." He's abused by Dallas cops, told to leave town and change his name, and generally despised as much as Lee.On Sunday morning, an official arrives at the Oswald home to inform them that Lee's been shot, but he's gonna be OK. Then a call comes in: JFK's accused killer is dead. Marguerite's reaction is incredible. She says, "My son is a hero, a government agent. They should bury him at Arlington alongside the president."We also learn of Dallas-based FBI agent James Hosty (Ron Livingston). He'd been tracking Oswald's activities for months, something Hosty's boss was unaware of. After they hear that Oswald's been arrested and is prime suspect in the assassination, Hosty is questioned about an incident that occurred just 10 days earlier. Oswald had stopped by CIA headquarters to both complain that Hosty was speaking to his wife and to threaten he'd blow the place up if these conversations continued. Hosty's boss explodes in anger, for this threat on a Federal facility, real or idle, was a felony and Oswald should've been immediately taken into custody for making it. If Hosty wants to save his job, he's ordered to burn his Oswald file. He does as he's told.There is so much more I haven't mentioned.If you're at all interested in this historic American tragedy, PARKLAND is an absolute must-see.

reviewText: I like the idea behind "Parkland," writer and director Peter Landesman's 2013 debut film based on Vincent Bugliosi's bookFour Days in November: The Assassination of President John F. Kennedy. Many dramas played out in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963, the tragic day when U.S. President John F. Kennedy was assassinated while traveling in that infamous motorcade. It was such a surreal occurrence, and every person caught up in the whirlwind of panic stood for a moment, ever so briefly, like the proverbial deer caught in headlights. After watching this film, I considered how much our world had changed. Crime, murder, spree killings -- such blood on the streets has become commonplace. Was this traumatic day a demented ground zero for a new society to follow?It's more complicated than that and "Parkland" has little time for such contemplation. Clocking in at 93 minutes, the film barely has time for the assassination. But the shooting indeed occurs 10 minutes in and the chaos of speeding cars, screaming secret service agents and slamming doors takes up the remainder of the work. I have no doubt panicky souls stumbled through this most unexpected historical moment. Where Landesman has succeeded is in the film's authenticity. The detail of an era half a century ago has been recreated with extraordinary care.But the great fault of this ultimately average film, is Landesman's inability to stage a shot with a stationary camera. Hand-held rules the day with awkward closeups, abrupt pans and rapid editing. Such modern techniques appear contrived for a period piece. This film is supposed to serve as a window into history, a unique privilege corrupted by Landesman's need to paint his work with rapid strokes. The day's drama was more than enough to hold the audience's interest. This miscalculation cheapens the film and dilutes several very good performances.Most notably is Paul Giamatti as Abraham Zapruder, the Dallas resident who fatefully filmed the assassination with his 8mm camera (Image of an Assassination - A New Look at the Zapruder Film). Giamatti's work, as usual, is excellent. But you have to watch closely as Landesman seems more interested in showing half of his face or cutting away quickly as if suffering from attention-deficit disorder. Giamatti's Zapruder is devastated by what he has filmed, and I was not aware he was convinced the president was dead immediately after the shooting.Zac Efron is provided his most appealing role as young resident Dr. Jim Carrico at Parkland Hospital, half asleep, who strolls into the emergency room to shockingly see the U.S. president lying on the stretcher (We Were There: Revelations from the Dallas Doctors Who Attended to JFK on November 22, 1963). He freezes, as any of us would, but with the assistance of ER Nurse Doris Nelson (Marcia Gay Harden), snaps into action. These frantic scenes, uncomfortably intimate and bloody to boot, are the highlight of "Parkland." Men and women desperately work to save the man's life while his wife Jacqueline (Kat Steffens) tearfully looks on. It is a devastating moment which brings the reality of this horrifying day to the surface like never before.The remainder of the film rarely reaches such heights as multiple characters are awkwardly followed. I appreciated the earnest performance of James Badge Dale as Robert Oswald, older brother of accused assassin Lee Harvey (Lee: A Portrait of Lee Harvey Oswald by His Brother). When he hears his brother's name on the radio, he's rendered speechless before leaving his office to visit the Dallas police station. He briefly talks to Lee during a fascinating scene. His accused brother offers nothing and essentially tells him not to worry -- "Don't get in trouble at work." The most telling part of this now-historic conversation is not even in the film, in which Robert asks Lee point blank, "Did you shoot the president?" Lee's answer, "Don't go there brother."The most famous film about the assassination is Oliver Stone'sJFK, the epic work from 1990 which chose to detail endless conspiracies surrounding the crime. Overrated and bombastic, it is never-the-less a dark thriller which plays like a nightmare. "Parkland" respectfully avoids any hint of conspiracy, choosing to provide only what is factually known. The trauma of this haunting day runs so deep it has yet to be defined. It's a shame Landesman chose a derivative, Vérité style obscuring his inspired idea. With patience and old-school dimension, this could have been a classic statement.

reviewText: This diffused and inconsistent portrayal of the events of 11/22/63 and the few days after it actually contains the kernel of a good idea:  the experiences of the medical personnel at Parkland Hospital as the gory bodies of John F. Kennedy, and, two days later, his accused assassin Lee Harvey Oswald, got wheeled on stretchers through their front door.  Can you even begin to imagine how mind-blowing all this must have been for the doctors and nurses who happened to work at this unlikely nexus?  Ground Zero for the events that forever changed, and, let's be honest, forever darkened America.Well, that's exactly what we don't get in "Parkland".  I had sort of hoped for a creatively conceived and well-written soap opera about the Assassination from the point of view of the hospital personnel and how the event changed their lives.  Instead what I got was yet another "lone gunman" brief via Vincent Bugliosi and producer Tom Hanks, in which Kennedy's blown-open head is never shown -- the hand-held camera dancing nervously around it -- and in which the doctors' observations about the nature of the bullet wounds are never discussed, because the inclusion of such material hurts Bugliosi's brief.  It seems that this subject matter is by its nature hopelessly partisan, and whichever side you stand on is going to color how you present the material and also how you view it as an audience.The partisanship gets worse when we step outside of the hospital.  We follow Abraham Zapruder (another excellent, if brief, performance by national treasure Paul Giamatti) as he makes the world's most famous home movie and is later accosted by the Secret Service and half the world's media.  When it's time to see what he actually captured, we end up getting a closer view of his grandkids on the same film than we get of the assassination itself.  Why?  Again, because it hurts Bugliosi's brief.  The Zapruder film clearly shows that the "kill shot" came from the right and front in relation to the President's location.  Welcome to the laws of physics:  "back, and to the left".  In "Parkland", we see this moment as reflected through Giamatti's eyeglasses as he watches in horror.  Whatever.  You can view it for yourself -- clearly, without reflection -- on countless uploads on YouTube.We also get to know Oswald's mother and brother.  As diagrammed in the movie, each character is designed to be a mouthpiece for the opposing points of view about the Assassination, the mother insisting Lee was framed, the brother instantly assuming Lee's guilt the moment he hears the name on the radio.  The mother is portrayed as a mean-spirited fruitcake who, if she had a long mustache, would be evilly twisting the ends of it.  "Tell LIFE Magazine I want my advance in CASH!"  Meanwhile, the brother stoically goes about the business of attending to the family's honor.  Guess who we're supposed to believe and sympathize with?  The prosecutor continues to make his case.  In any case, neither character is real; they're cartoons, and would've stayed that way even if they'd had more screen-time.However, we're puzzled when the movie starts blowing apart its own brief when it goes to the local FBI offices and the mini-drama surrounding Agent James Hosty.  Without belaboring the details, I think the filmmakers are trying to explain that what happened to the FBI's dossier on Oswald was a typical CYA operation so common with bureaucracies ... but, ironically, the very admission of a cover-up, even a mundane one as presented, only encourages conspiracy-mongering.  The prosecution loses that round badly.Anyway, it was interesting to learn how the Secret Service managed to get the Presidential coffin aboard Air Force One without having to dump it in the cargo hold.  The depiction of Jackie as a desolated angel, however, doesn't quite ring true with the footage available or with the testimony of witnesses who were almost appalled by her resoluteness.  This movie has her crying throughout.  Jackie wasn't much of a crier.Vincent Bugliosi is a prosecutor.  Prosecutors prefer clear-cut cases where a perpetrator commits a crime and is punished for it.  You know what? -- he may even be right in this case.  But he may be wrong.  His, and the Warren Commission's, theory is just one of many.  When we're on a jury, a lawyer will present ... and withhold ... evidence that will help persuade us to his or her point of view. reviewText: Based on Vincent Bugliosi's book retelling the events leading up to and following the Kennedy assassination on a minute-by-minute basis, PARKLAND is a low-key film that eschews sensationalism in favor of characterization.  Director Peter Landesman focuses on the reactions of those involved in the affair, notably Dr. Jim Carrico (Zac Efron), who treated JFK at the Parkland Hospital, and FBI agent James Hosty (Ron Livingston).  The film is shot in cinéma-vérité style, with lots of quick cuts and close-ups on the protagonists with the minimum of climatic scenes.  Sometimes the action drags slightly, but PARKLAND's main concern is to illuminate the human cost of the tragedy - for example, the reaction of dressmaker Abraham Zapruder (Paul Giamatti), whose amateur film of the tragedy constituted the only available record of what actually happened.  Director Landesman shows how the emotional effect of being regularly interrogated by the FBI proved too much for him.  We also see the reaction of the nurses in the Parkland Hospital, who strove to save the President's life but eventually failed.  Compared to other versions of the event - for example, Oliver Stone's JFK - PARKLAND lacks sensationalism. but is nonetheless extremely well made, a testament to the efforts of everyone involved, actors, directors and those behind the camera alike.
summary: Sober Re-Telling of a Momentous Event

reviewText: I purchased this film for my Kindle Fire. I have been interested in this event since it happened when I was in 1st Grade. I remember that day well. My brother, sister, and I had come home from school for lunch and returned to school. This was a treat because my Dad had a long weekend from his job. He was repainting the ceiling in our family room and living room. And, my Dad was looking forward to the weekend Notre Dame football game on television. My Mom was taking care of my youngest sister who was not school age yet.My siblings and I returned to our respective classrooms. About 1:15 pm CST, our school principal came to our classroom. He was a tall, thin, man about 30 years old. The principal was very serious and not even trying to smile. He told our class that President Kennedy was hurt very badly while visiting Dallas, Texas. Because not much was known about what happened to the President, school was being dismissed as soon as possible. Parents had been called to pick up their children and we were not going to have school on Monday. In relatively short order, we went to our lockers. I remember an occasional drizzle; my Dad was waiting in our family car for us. He was sitting behind the steering wheel and starring at the car radio which he had on. It was not playing music. The newsman was on talking and saying that President Kennedy had been shot to death in Dallas, Texas. This did not make sense to me. President Kennedy was youngish like my Dad. Too young to be dead. Soon, we were home. My Mom was sitting on our sofa. She was very sad and holding my younger sister. My Dad said to my Mom that Johnson would call up the Army and he was still young enough to be recalled (he was a WWII veteran). My Dad was very solemn.That is my personal background. I really don't care about Vincent Bugliosi's spin on the Assassination. Frankly, it is refried hash of the discredited Warren Report. There are factual problems with the film. Claudia Johnson was very kind and considerate of Mrs. Kennedy at Parkland Hospital and offered her sympathy. Johnson was extraordinarily subdued. He said little and was isolated in the protective Secret Service agent cordon that had been established. These facts are not included. Another fact left out is the Trauma team of Carrico and Perry in particular indicating that the throat wound is a bullet entry wound which is not mentioned at all in this film which is carrying a particular author's spin too far. Whoever was portraying Sen. Ralph Yarborough is not shown at all. There are other events left out of the Trauma Room 1 scenes. This part is dramatic but it is not thorough in presentation. This event is too well known through many sources. Jim Bishop's The Day Kennedy Was Shot and the Jacqueline Kennedy disavowed William Manchester tome, The Death of a President and still others.Then, there are the Abraham Zapruder scenes. The actor for this part is okay. What is not okay is the shorthand with his film. Dan Rather, CBS Dallas Bureau Chief, learns of the Zapruder film and encourages Zapruder to get it developed which Zapruder does. In the meantime, the Secret Service learns of its existence and so does Time/Life executive CD Jackson, a publisher with CIA connections. This is not pointed out in the film at all--and here is a telling flaw in this film. Selective censoring of the facts that occurred. I do not want Bugliosi's version of events--that version contains a deep seated bias, wishing Lee Oswald guilty with no other possibility entertained at all. Unfortunately, Oswald will always remain termed either "the suspected assassin" or "the alleged assassin" because the US Constitution expressly prohibits trying suspects posthumously no matter how heinous the crime. The Zapruder film is shown, sort of, edited in such a way as nothing of substance is seen. Odd. The Zapruder film has been shown in documentaries, news programs on the networks, and in other films. So, what is the nonsense with not showing the Zapruder film in this movie?Dr. Earl Rose, Medical Examiner for Dallas County, Texas is shown asserting Texas law regarding post mortems for local murders and the Secret Service agents. Frankly, both sides had some right on their respective sides. Mrs. Kennedy being left behind in Dallas had the potential for risking her life or being held by the confederates of the assassin(s) to pressure Washington, DC into granting as of yet unknown demands. Did it not occur to anyone on President Kennedy's staff such as Kennedy Chief of Staff Kenny O'Donnell to ask Dr. Rose to join them on AF1 in order to conduct the autopsy in the safety of Washington, DC or its environs?This movie had the potential for a realistic portrayal of historic events. Instead, it devolves into caricatures and draws its characters as mere shadows. Liberties are taken with verifiable facts--those liberties are an insult to anyone who was around when this murder happened. Disappointing.Because I have an extensive library of Kennedy Assassination materials: books, one newspaper, films and DVD's, etc., I will place it with those materials; however, it is placed by the long discredited Warren Report.

reviewText: PARKLAND (Writ./Dir. Peter Landesman, based on the book by Vincent Bugliosi, 2013, 94 minutes, Playtone Productions) is titled after the name of the Dallas hospital where JFK was taken the day he was assassinated, and is the story of that day and the following three days. It has a very bouncy and slightly annoying "you-are-there" cinematographic style which I always despise, but at least they tried not to overdo it.This film is a no-frills, no-nonsense look at the events of those four days and follows a few paths: Abraham Zapruder (a captivating Paul Giamatti performance but then again, when isn't he captivating) and his film's development. The Dallas Secret Service, in particular Agent Sorrels (a most excellent Billy Bob Thornton). The FBI and their desperation in the knowledge that they were surveilling Oswald. Finally, the film follows two very weird parallels no one ever thinks about:It followed then-First Lady Mrs. Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson but it also followed Lee Harvey Oswald's brother Bob and their mother. Though a few know of Oswald's widow and children (this film shows a daughter but I thought he had more), it seems no one knew about Bob Oswald, how he stayed in Dallas, raised his kids there and never changed his name. He lived to a ripe old age and I was astonished by that fact.The most astonishing thing I think I learned was that Oswald was taken to Parkland Hospital after he was shot. They refused to allow him to go into the OR where the President had been; we also see his pathetic funeral. Other astonishing things are to be seen (or not) in this movie. I was taken aback at the lack of accuracy in a few instances. To the viewer I leave it, to find those examples.Finally, as I said, there are no conspiracy theories addressed here, no "grassy knoll shooter", and the film distinctly and clearly lets us hear three gunshots. This is because Bugliosi's original work was meant to debunk all conspiracy theories and this film sticks to that spirit.An element I loved about the approach is best illustrated by an example: Zapruder keeps filming though at first he does not seem to grasp what he has filmed, and it is at this stunning cinematic moment, with the attention on Zapruder, when we hear the shots. Zapruder hears them and sort of grunts in a distracted way, as if he thought it had been a car backfiring. Yet moments later when he finishes filming he is yelling that the president has been killed.I'm perplexed at Giamatti's apparent acting slip-up (why does he seem oblivious to what he is filming?), unless this was the editor's fault. Either way it is a glaring and annoying problem in such an emotional and otherwise well done scene.Yet there are some "dummy" moments too, which I am in no way sufficiently expert to address beyond how dumb they look in the film: an example is the extensive scene when Bob Oswald visits his mother in the police interrogation room. He is allowed to interrogate her--which he does with some apparent experience--and she seems like a crazy old lady. Come on, people, really? The police did not arrest the whole family at least for a short while? Not even for their protection? And then here's Bob Oswald questioning Mrs. Oswald alone in a police interrogation room.Another example I can cite is one character--and I admit I do not know who he is, which is significant--persistently addresses the First Lady as "Jackie". The fifteenth time I heard it I was almost ready to stop watching, but the film frankly was good enough to prevent me. Also vital in my decision to keep watching was Giamatti, since I watch nearly everything he does.Much of this movie's weird spirit, in fact, is the only minor beef I have with this movie aside from the anachronisms, errors and Zac Efron being used as a cardboard cutout (he can't really act anyway but still). The problem is a double-trouble scenario and it involves the authorities allowing the civvies to run things. Abraham Zapruder is treated here as if he were in control of the development of the film--and the moment Agent Sorrels impounds custody of the film, he immediately and totally gives it back to Zapruder's custody.Do you really believe the authorities worked like that?--what's worse, the police (or sheriff's department) seem to put Bob Oswald in charge of investigating his family (meaning his mad old mother). It overstrains credulity to expect the audience to believe that Zapruder on the one hand and Bob Oswald on the other are two important men in charge of things here. I may be wrong, but as I recall Zapruder developed his film and studied it, only later involving the authorities. Until that time, they did not know about Zapruder, and he didn't know he had actually filmed the president's assassination.Wallywood strikes again ....It was extremely well done, as was the entire film and most especially was the use of genuine media, radio, TV of the time instead of trying to recreate those announcements. I liked the prominence of David Brinkley and Walter Cronkite. As a historical dramatization, let's just say it's clear a lot of people are bobbing for awards here but the film has tremendous value. No one has ever made a film like this, covering these basics--and after this, I suspect no one will ever make another film about it.Amazon customers/readers, this is a film review as you ought to know. Please, do not post comments under my review about how stupid my review is, how the history is all wrong, things of that nature ... please, comment on the film, I beg you, or not at all. If it makes you feel better, for many of the same reasons I love Oliver Stone'sJFK....After all, I didn't make the movie--I'm just reviewing the thing. As lacking as it was in some ways, I really liked it overall and recommend it highly.

reviewText: The date November 22, 1963, is one of the darkest days in American history.  On this particular day, the United States was thrust into a tailspin when an assassin's bullet struck down President John F. Kennedy while he was riding in his motorcade through the streets of Dallas, Texas.  As if the tragedy of this day weren't horrific enough, the JFK assassination is also one of the most heavily analyzed events because of the sudden disarray the government experienced - never mind the possibility of a massive cover-up.  Naturally, the series of events in Dallas has prompted the creation of several Hollywood productions, including JFK, Executive Action, and In the Line of Fire.  Most of those films focus on the assassination directly, but there really hasn't been a film that focuses on the individuals that played an essential role in trying to save JFK and protect his body after his death - until now.  In the new film, Parkland - the doctors and the video tape that documented the assassination take center stage.Based on the book Reclaiming History: The Assassination of President John F. Kennedy by Vincent Bugliosi and directed by Peter Landesman, Parkland stars Paul Giamatti as Abraham Zapruder, the man that videotaped the assassination of John F. Kennedy.  Word quickly spreads that someone had the events on camera, prompting Secret Service Agent Forrest Sorrels (Billy Bob Thornton) to have it quickly developed.  At the same time, JFK's body was transported to Parkland Hospital where the doctors on staff, including Dr. Jim Carrico (Zac Efron) and Dr. Malcom O. Perry (Colin Hanks), attempted to save the president's life.  Following the president's death, the Secret Service controversially reclaim the body and move to return the yet to be sword in Vice President, Lyndon B. Johnson, to Washington D.C.  Tom Welling, Mark Duplass, Jacki Weaver, James Badge Dale, and Jackie Earle Haley also star in supporting roles.While I'm a diehard lover of history, there's just something about most history films that always leave a bad taste in my mouth.  The abundance of history flicks is usually a good thing (as far as the entertainment value goes) and if they help get more people interested in history, that's great.  Films about history figures, like Abraham Lincoln, are always interesting because he was never documented on video.  My beef is with films, like Parkland and W., that depict events that don't require a Hollywood production.  For instance, George W. Bush is alive and well, and most everything he ever did in office is quickly interpreted in a mere two hours in W.  What's the point?  Everything the man has done is basically on camera for anyone to watch on YouTube or through various media outlets.  The same goes for the JFK assassination, especially since there is an abundance of documentaries - some presenting the facts and others full of conspiracy theories, that chronicles the events of his assassination.  My point here is that many of the real life people, including Abraham Zapruder and Dr. Malcom O. Perry, are all on record depicting their version of events.  There's no need to create (at this point in time) a seemingly pointless reproduction using famous actors to depict already well-documented events.Parkland attempts to bite off more than it can chew, often throwing a ton of brutally important information at you in a short amount of time.  It follows several different plot lines, including the Zapruder tape, JFK's trip to the hospital, Lee Harvey Oswald's brother and mother, and a handful of Secret Service members.  And, the worst part about all of it is the fact that each of these subjects, which have books written about them on their own, are terribly minimized - while other subjects, like the possibility of a different shooter other than Oswald, is completely trivialized.  More often than not, Parkland lacks a driving point and a clear cut message.  Sure, the film has its facts in order, but it would appear this film's only goal was to show the expressions of people's faces during this devastating day.  I don't know about you, but Zac Efron looking at JFK's body lying lifeless on a table doesn't exactly "move" me.In some scenes, more than others, the emotion of the situation is understandably devastating - especially when JFK is lying on a hospital bed as doctors and officials look on helplessly.  There no actor on this planet that could fully encompass the emotions that were flowing on this day.  Still, standing out in this star-studded cast is Paul Giamatti, who is no stranger to historical character acting.  He masterfully portrayed former U.S. President John Adams in an HBO miniseries, and does an equally superb job here as the emotionally distraught and highly conflicted Abraham Zapruder.  James Badge Dale is also quite captivating as Lee Harvey Oswald's brother, Robert.  Dale, along with Jacki Weaver as Marguerite Oswald, brings an interesting dynamic to the screen - showing the reaction of Lee's family members.  Needless to say, the cast is mostly enjoyable, but because of the nature of this story, there really is no main character.In my opinion, you shouldn't need to watch a Hollywood production for modern historical knowledge.  Even though this film coincides with the 50th anniversary of the event, the history of the JFK assassination is heavily documented and now chronicled in-depth by using a minute by minute recap of what was happening.  In any event, Parkland gives attention to individuals that aren't typically in the limelight, focusing on the actions of the doctors, casual observers, along with members of the Oswald family.  Obviously, the portrayed characters of this film play substantial roles in the post-assassination history, making the film a moderately moving experience for those looking to reflect on that day.  In that regard, Parkland is very conventional at times, but the clear goal of this film was obviously to reenact and modernize a tragedy for a new generation.  The problem with that is the various history channels on cable television still do a better job of sharing these events.GRADE: C-FNDNreview.com

reviewText: The film is called Parkland but it has very little to do with the Dallas, Texas hospital for which it is named. Anyone awaiting the long overdo story of the doctors and nurses who first tended to President Kennedy's body following the horrific events of November 22, 1963, may be disappointed. For anyone aware that the Parkland Memorial physicians were all in agreement concerning the findings of the Warren Commission and the "official" autopsy of the President's body were totally contrary to what they saw with their own eyes, the film may border on insulting. For a film purportedly about facts, Parkland is astonishingly opinionated. It's a fact that Marguerite Oswald thought her son Lee was an intelligence agent framed for the murder of President Kennedy. It's also a fact that Lee's brother Robert, whom Lee looked up to (Lee was wearing Robert's Marine ring at the time of his arrest -- a point strangely left out of the film), never had any doubts that Lee acted alone and was the sole killer of the President as well as Dallas police officer J.D. Tippet. And I suppose it should be noted that it's indeed a fact Lee Harvey Oswald was tried and convicted by the media and the powers that be in the court of public opinion, before he ever stepped foot out of a Dallas holding cell -- all the while professing his innocence and wrongful arrest. It's a shame that Parkland failed to portray that last particular truth with any clarity in its handling of the seemingly exact and lesser known details that tense and gory day in late November, 1963, some 50 years ago this very month. Not entirely unlike it's predecessor, Oliver Stone's JFK, Parkland has an agenda to expound. Whereas the aim of Stone's densely populated film of characters and ideas was to present ALL the theories it could surrounding the Garrison investigation of a likely conspiracy (later confirmed "likely" by our own government), Parkland seems more concerned with passing the research and imagination of one man (writer Vincent Bugliosi) as absolute truth. There's no room for doubt in these proceedings: Oswald was guilty, but the real truth is: his own death kept a lot of white a$$es out of jail (and ostensibly in office) forever crystallizing the mystery surrounding his actual involvement. Otherwise, it's a nearly unwatchable display of amateur theatrics and wasted talent.Zac Efron looks like he wandered onto the big boy's stage fresh from a teen magazine photo spread. He's completely out of his range playing a young resident physician at Parkland Hospital and thoroughly incapable of portraying any semblance of an internal life. He's simply there to look attractive and pound on the dead President's chest in utter desperation after it's too late to save him. With all due respect, he's a good pounder. Billy Bob Thornton portrays Forrest Sorrels, the man (as far as I'm concerned) who was totally at fault for the Secret Service's epic blunder in not protecting Lancer (as Kennedy was known to his Agents; also not mentioned in the film) as well as the biggest f-up in the history of Presidential protection (which is more or less stated in the film at one point). But who was he? All we are led to believe is that Sorrels was a competent, forthright man whose negligence (or over-confidence) gave birth to tragic repercussions. Billy Bob Thornton seems intent on playing him as plainly and believably as possible, as if he were doing some sort of service to a relatively unknown but flawed man. The flaw is not in the way he is played, but rather in what we know today about the real character: which is next to nothing. I have a feeling that Bugliosi took a great many liberties in conjuring up the way Sorrels thought and acted that historic day, but what he doesn't provide is clear enough evidence that Kennedy would not have died by a sniper's bullet had this one man have simply done his job. And why wasn't he held professionally accountable for not protecting the President? Why wasn't anyone? These are not questions explored in Parkland. Rather, Parkland chooses to focus on good people under extreme duress who were forced to make hard decisions (such as where exactly Kennedy's coffin will be situated on Air Force One) whether they were indirectly responsible for the crime or not. The names of critical figures in the story appear on screen in lieu of actual character development; this is afterall a film on the go with a lot of inconsequential material to get through. Speaking of "development", a great deal of the early action is spent on the efforts by Abraham Zapruder and the Secret Service to develop the 8mm footage Zapruder fortuitously captured while standing not less than thirty feet away from the murder scene. Zapruder is played by Paul Giamatti who (not surprisingly) turns in the most full-bodied performance.Zapruder starts off giddy to be closing up shop across the street at the Dal-Tex Building, telling all of his lovely-dressed employees that they must all go outside to see the President's motorcade pass. Fate would have it that Zapruder and his secretary would choose the most ideal spot imaginable to take what is widely considered the most important film ever shot in US history. This realization, along with the sickening images he witnessed through the camera lens, are forever engraved on his face thereafter. Zapruder was not a man who held the fate of the President in his own hands, he was simply a guy on his lunch break. He and Sorrels would both etch themselves into history as a result of their choices. It's just a shame that Parkland doesn't draw any real connection between the two. Instead, it just puts them together in several scenes and reminds us that these are names we should all know. Ron Livingston as FBI Agent James Hosty is portrayed as a victim of another sort. Hosty's name should be familiar to fans of the Stone movie, as he was the man who kept a file on Oswald months before the assassination. In the Parkland film, he is not a possible accomplice in a conspiracy, he is simply ordered by his superiors to destroy any evidence that the FBI even knew who Lee Harvey Oswald was, before it makes them look bad for not potentially stopping the President's killer. It's a plausible turn of events I suppose, and one that Hosty clung to for most of his life (he eventually wrote a book) but what we don't get is the context surrounding any of his actions. Hosty was never asked by the Warren Commission anything that could incriminate him or the FBI, therefore he never technically lied about anything, or did anything wrong -- technically speaking. He destroyed the letter that Oswald hand-delivered to him (at the FBI building) supposedly in which Oswald threatened Hosty's life if he didn't leave his family alone, allegedly because Hosty saw it as a personal letter to him, and therefore not an official document. The mere inclusion of Hosty in Parkland opens a whole can of worms that these filmmakers were neither willing nor capable of delving into. It's the only form of cover-up or conspiracy that we are shown on an official level in Parkland and it damns the whole film. The Dallas police are simply portrayed as ignorant and bullying hicks (not likely far from the truth), but the FBI are revealed to be positively traitorous in their actions surrounding the murder investigation of a Commander in Chief. And I can only assume according to Bugliosi and co., that's A-ok simply because no one ever asked them about it on the record. Also of interest, the film neglects to mention the fact that the FBI and the Secret Service already thwarted an assassination plot on Kennedy's life in Chicago weeks before the trip into hostile Dallas territory (Thomas Arthur Vallee among others was apprehended, an ex-Marine with alleged Communist credentials eerily similar to Oswald). Kennedy Secret Service Man Abraham Bolden wrote a book about it in which he also claims that several members of Kennedy's own Secret Service detail on the Texas trip stated in private they would not take a bullet for Kennedy. All fascinating details (and every bit as relevant as the personal beliefs and claims of Robert Oswald) that have come to light and were left out of Parkland presumably because they detract from the outmoded lone gunman tract.The Oswald family (Marguerite, Robert and Lee) make brief appearances at several stages to help the filmmakers reinforce the official story (official in 1963 anyway) that Oswald was the lone assassin. Marguerite, played here by Jacki Weaver (who was riveting in Animal Kingdom) is the only character crying conspiracy (other than Lee who only hints at it). None of the Oswalds provide a rationale for his actions, only that he is either solely guilty or the victim of something greater. I suppose that's all any of us think today of Lee Harvey Oswald. If you believe the Warren Commission fiction, you must be an anti-conspiracy nut; if you don't buy it, you're just a conspiracy nut. Parkland, the first major film project to put the audience face to face with the President's alleged killer (or patsy) since Gary Oldman in JFK doesn't do much to reconcile these two schools of thought. The scene between Robert and Lee (played adequately by James Badge Dale and Jeremy Strong respectively) excels at showing Lee to be off-kilter and cocky, even in the face of imminent danger, yet it somehow only feels like the intended high point of a low end production.If you want to know what else the Warren Commission purposely didn't ask anyone about (for their own protection), see Stone's JFK. John Kennedy is not an actual character in the film JFK, but his very presence, or ghost, seems to loom over all the events transpiring. It's a testament to how well the film is made, be it fantasy or not. The ghost of John Kennedy is nowhere to be felt in Parkland, despite his dead body being lugged around from one shouting match to another, and his familiar face being shown from time to time on newsreels reminding us that a real person was killed, not just a public figure. There are other real people on display in the film too, but their connection to reality is still highly suspect.

reviewText: "Parkland" is a recounting of the chaotic events that occurred at Dallas' Parkland Hospital on the day U.S. President John F. Kennedy was assassinated. The film takes it title from the hospital where both Kennedy and his killer, Lee Harvey Oswald,  were pronounced dead."Parkland" revisits the assassination of President Kennedy as the tragedy's fiftieth anniversary approaches. Writer-director Peter Landesman provides an up-close-and-personal view of the events in Dallas by following the intertwined stories of several people swept up in the shooting and its aftermath.The President was rushed to Parkland, where a shocked medical team, led by Dr. Jim Carrico, (Zac Efron), desperately tried to revive him long after he was gone. Marcia Gay Harden is the head nurse at the scene. Efron and Harden both give intense portraits of stunned professionals stretched to their limits trying to keep the President Kennedy alive. Blood-spattered Jackie Kennedy sobs nearby.As news of the death shocked the nation, the story rippled outward, following several characters who are peripheral to the tragedy. Overbearing FBI veteran Forrest Sorrels, (Billy Bob Thornton), and his cohorts wrested Zapruder's film from him to have it developed ASAP. Life magazine and other outlets scrambled to purchase rights to the film. Dallas FBI agent James Hosty, (Ron Livingston), realized and agonized over his prior contact with Lee Harvey Oswald, (Jeremy Strong). However, Hosty did not know about Oswald's future macabre' plans in time to to stop him. Then there is the confused scene at the Dallas jail where Oswald was held until he too was assassinated.The film's focus is not on the President, his wife, the newly sworn-in President, Lyndon B. Johnson, or conspiracy theories. Rather  the horror is seen through the eyes of the people who experienced the catastrophic event firsthand on that fateful day in Dallas.  Paul Giamatti masterfully plays Abraham Zapruder, as a man so overwhelmed by the magnitude of the tragedy that it takes him a while to realize what an unintentionally huge role his humble little home movie will play in the unfolding drama. Lee Harvey Oswald, his brother Bob, his mother and wife also have their parts to play here. "Parkland" treats Kennedy as a symbol of hope and optimism, but also, as a fatally injured body, and then as a corpse whose remains must be examined and then transported to a final resting place.Some of the visuals are experienced through expressions on people's faces and gasps of shock, especially the Secret Service detail when they watch the film. Their expressions and grief are gut wrenching. Some of the footage is visible, (but not the "kill-scene,)" through reflections from Zapruder sunglasses. Landesman and cinematographer Barry Ackroyd shoot the action verité-style, with a lot of rushed camera movements and reliance on telephoto close-ups. This style of filming enhances the feeling of chaos.Mr. Landesman, a journalist and novelist, adapted the story from Vincent Bugliosi’s 2008 book, “Four Days in November,”As with most other people, I clearly remember where I was when our President,  John F. Kennedy, was murdered. The events of Dallas destroyed a lot of my dreams & my innocence. I was only 18 years-old when his violent death embedded itself onto my memory forever.JANA
summary: The events of Dallas 1963 destroyed a lot of my dreams & my innocence.

reviewText: There have been many movies, TV shows and documentaries made over the years that look back at the tragic events that took place in Dallas Texas in November 1963. One of the better ones to be made is the recent film "Parkland". Well written, acted and directed "parkland is an interesting look at President Kennedy's assassination because it covers events that usually are not covered or talked about that much on that fateful day that gives a whole new perspective to what occurred. In particular it looks at three individual situations that would be occurring at about the same time. First the film looks at what took place inside the examination room at Parkland Hospital, thus where the title comes from, as the mortally wounded President is wheeled in. It shows what the doctors went through dealing with who the patient was and the severity of the gun shot wound. It would also look at the power struggle that would take place in that examination room between the Secret Service who were still loyal to their slain leader and Dallas government  officials who were insisting the body of JFK was now in their possession because an autopsy needed to be conducted by Dallas law. The Secret Service men on the other hand wanted to get the body of Kennedy, Mrs. Kennedy and the now new President Lyndon Johnson out of Dallas and back to Washington D C  as soon as possible for everyones safety and concern. As the movie shows emotions ran very high in that examination room. Later on the movie you watch inside Parkland Hospital again when in the examination room across the hall from where President Kennedy died the doctors struggle to save the life of the man who would be accused of killing the President. These are some of the most intense scenes you will seen in the movie but they are not the only ones.Another intense situation is the look at Abraham Zapruder a business man with a new movie camera who plans to film President and Mrs.Kennedy in their motorcade as they drive by. What would end up happening  however is Mr. Zapruder would capture the moment the fatal shot would hit the President. The story behind that is told here from Zapruder filming that infamous moment to getting the film developed to how Mr. Zapruder was affected by what he witnessed. A lot of people may know of Abraham Zapruder and what he recorded but few probably know of what he went through because of what he recorded.The other interesting story told here is how the family of Lee Harvey Oswald was affected by the actions of Lee Harvey. In particular it looks at Oswald's mother and brother and what they went through and endured all because of what Oswald did and the price they had to pay for those actions.For those of us who are old enough to remember that day, and I am just old enough to remember myself, this movie will bring back the memories. You will find yourself thinking back to what you were doing as all these events take place. For those not old enough to remember or weren't even born yet this movie will prove to be an excellent history lesson. "Parkland" is a must for all to see at least once. It will grab your attention and compel you to watch, it is that strong of a movie.

reviewText: 2013 marks the 50th anniversary of the assassination of John F. Kennedy.  "Parkland" explores the chaotic four days in Dallas through the eyes of the hospital workers who worked to revive JFK and later Lee Harvey Oswald, the Secret Service workers who were charged with protecting the President, and family members, including Oswald's brother Robert and his mother, who were forced to live with the repercussions of the actions of others.The film begins with Kennedy's motorcade proceeding through the streets of Dallas.  Kennedy is shot, and the Presidential limo speeds toward Parkland, where the only doctor initially on duty is a resident (Zac Efron).  The staff members of parkland fight heroically to save Kennedy, but to no avail.  Next, the movie proceeds to the events concerning the Secret Service, including the seizure of the Zapruder film and the struggle to have Kennedy's body released for the flight back to Washington, D.C.  The viewer also gets a look at the brother and mother of Lee Harvey Oswald."Parkland" is one of the best movies I've seen.  The historical timeline is accurate, and the scenes in the Parkland operating room, while most definitely graphic, are historically correct.  The acting is top-notch, and Billy Bob Thornton, James Badge Dale, and Zac Efron all give first-rate performances.  "Parkland" is destined to become one of the definitive movies about the Kennedy assassination.  Highly, highly recommended.

The acting was excellent from each main character. The hospital scenes were gripping.  I have had people tell me in advance that the camera was too shaky.  Nope, it's just fine.  Other TV shows are much more annoying in that regard.  Since this is shot to feel like you were in the room and in the scenes, the hand held camera work is excellent without being distracting at all.  Kudos to the camera person's, DP and the director.There was no recreation of the assassination, as it's been done before Ad Nauseum and was not need to be done to further the storyline or benefit the film my opinion either. Showing the assassination with a camera locked strictly on Zapruder (that's how the film makers represented the assassination scene) filming with him 8mm camera, well,it was a little awkward as the shot seemed long... but later, using the Zapruder film was a creative idea as the moments of the assassination are reflected into Abraham Zapruder's glasses in a scene where he initially watches what he filmed that fateful day.Many have said that Zack Efron was miscast, I give him credit that his acting worked in the scenes though. I can see why some will say his typecasting was a distraction.  Tom Welling (Smallville) played an excellent role as a secret service agent.None of the actors really got to sink their teeth into this since it was all a fast paced and albeit short film considering the subject matter that COULD have been explored.  No actors spent too much time on screen as it was very paced.Paul Giamatti (Abraham Zapruder) David Harbour (FBI AGENT) and Billy Bob Thorton (SECRET SERVICE) are memorable as you saw different emotional scenes with them. James Badge Dale was excellent as well as Robert Oswald, LHO's brother...The FBI HQ scenes were (for me) very realistic.  The set design/scenery and the overall atmosphere the production team tried to create was real.  The guys smoking, the period clothes and haircuts, it all reminded me of the time. The scenes with Ron Livingston and David Harbor (Agents) were some of the best as they come to grips with the fact that they had LHO in their office just weeks before and could have possibly "stopped" the assasination.  I found myself (a big fan of movies) really forgetting about the production requirements (all the behind the scene stuff) and getting into the scenes emotionally.They left out any mention of Governor John Connolly... I found this really wrong and out of place as he was a big part of the story.CAMERAWORKThe film makers avoided spending time or money on many of the key players in this tragic story.  The film was shot quite tight (framed close) probably keep the budget down and the money was surely spent on having the right talent, but it works because it plays better on emotion to do more close ups.  the actors were then forced to provide better facial expressions too.I was totally expecting to see a "Behind The Scenes" making of this film.  It's come to be expected and was really expecting some interviews and behind the scenes footage as a documentary. Unfortunately the Blu-Ray does not provide this. There are about 10 'deleted' scenes and a Director Commentary audio setup and subtitles.I must say, that the actors portraying Lee Harvey Oswald (Jeremy Strong) was totally excellent and underused. I wanted to see more scenes that included him. I guess I wanted to see what could have been - a world where Oswald survived to stand trial. The actor portraying him did well for the little time he was onscreen.  And mother Oswald...wow.  If that was really her persona, the actor who portrayed her (Jackie Weaver) really stole the scenes she appeared in.The Blu-Ray is worth buying as the price is very reasonable.
summary: Great Movie, really light - minimal additional disc content

reviewText: 'Parkland' is an amazing film, particularly considering it was the creation of a first-time writer-director, Peter Landesman (based on Vincent Bugliosi's book, `Four Days In November';  the size of which nearly rivaled the Affordable Health Care act) and then to be ultimately made on such a small budget and shot in 24 days.  Landesman has said that every American has a version of this movie in their head.  "Parkland' definitely takes us into the heads of some of the most prominently involved, if not publically known, individuals.I was 20 when President Kennedy was assassinated.  It was America's first brush with a tragedy of this sort playing out on our TV screens instantaneously and for many subsequent days in, for those days, an unprecedented television event, although now an exercise repeated too often for good taste.  America and Americans were much more innocent in that era and technology was limited and somewhat still in its pioneer days.  For the 10 years following the assassination I purchased and read anything printed about the tragedy.  To say I was familiar with the details would be stating it mildly.  Following that decade of close study of the circumstances surrounding Kennedy's death, I moved on with my life.  When new information or re-hashes of old information were in the newspapers, it barely made a blip on my news radar or my emotional scale.  Thus, I did not expect to be affected by 'Parkland' to any great emotional degree.`Parkland', with the cast, the directing, the script, and the sets combined, was able to take me back completely to, not just those three days, but individual minutes of those days; where I was, what I felt, who I was with, and how that weekend unfolded.  The film accomplished this in such an enveloping way that I was shocked at my own reaction.The intent, as stated by Landesman, was to present the story in compressed time and to focus on the doctors who treated President Kennedy and on those individuals in charge of Kennedy's safety, as well as Mr. Zapruder, who I saw in this film as sort of an everyman.  'Parkland' reminds us as well of many aspects of the events that will never be repeated should such a tragedy ever occur in America in the future.  Life has changed, government is very different, society has evolved in a not particularly positive manner, and individuals today are, sadly, not what we were then.  America has changed and it is sad.From the moment you hear the severely traumatized Abraham Zapruder repeatedly screaming, 'they've hilled him', whether you experienced the incident on TV as an adult or whether you barely know who John F. Kennedy is, you are emotionally involved in this awful day and the events which closely followed. 'Parkland', while not glamorizing or exploiting the actual physical details of the assassination, locks us instead inside a very small room where we never were; the Emergency Room of a busy hospital, with rookie doctors, more seasoned nurses, and many, many individuals under extreme duress.  Today there would be at least one newsman and cameraman as a pool media person to document for the public what Americans had not before witnessed.  You see the vision of the very real crushing impact that the loss of 'their man', President Kennedy' had on his Secret Service agents and the feats they accomplished, spurred on by their intense dedication for the very loved, very special  individual under their protection. Zapruder's personal response to the killing of 'his' president is depicted closely and directly symbolizes to the viewer the reaction of regular Americans to such a shocking loss.Each member of the low-waged cast gave us one of their best performances.  Particularly the following three:  Billy Bob Thornton, as Forrest Sorrels, head of the Dallas Secret Service Office, gave a steady, understated, thoroughly believable performance.  He portrayed a man in Sorrel's position perfectly, depicting him professionally doing his job while containing his emotions and yet  managing to fully display his deep feelings simultaneously.  I expected nothing less from Thornton, a brilliant actor who never disappoints and always shows us full blown characters, each perfectly nuanced in every detail, regardless of the size of the role, including, in this instance of Sorrels the small, but impactful, body language, subtly conveying a man suddenly carrying the weight of the world;  Zac Efron thoroughly nailed the young doctor, Charles 'Jim' Carrico, a new E.R. physician who was suddenly and unexpectedly thrust into working desperately to save the most important patient ever to present for his care, a patient who was already unfortunately lost. The strain of the realization of what was happening under his hands was provocatively present on Efron's face, in his eyes, and through his body language; Abraham Zapruder, the only one of these three main characters that most of the public has actually seen, was depicted through the spot-on performance of consummate actor, Paul Giamatti.  Mr. Zapruder was never the same after that day and died at relatively a young age, likely due to the strain of the incident and the impact the loss of President Kenney, whom he so greatly admired. Giamatti never missed a beat in sharing the instant changing impact the tragedy had upon Zapruder at once.  Giamatti's reenactment of Zapruder's plaintive cries immediately following the assassination were utterly and stunningly chilling and a perfect representation by one man of the sound the entire country was vocalizing individually at that very moment.  Marcia Gay Harden and Ron Livingston, as well as every member of the cast, also gave amazingly strong performances for this film.`Parkland' regardless of the constraints under which it was filmed, is a must-see movie.  The fact that it went apparently straight to DVD was a rude surprise and a shame really.  A larger audience should be seeing this film.  I recommend it for every teen and adult in the country, regardless of their age at the time of the event, their political leaning, their interest in history as a broad subject, or of any other factor, and instead just because this is a very real, very authentic depiction of an American tragedy that warrants a look 50 years beyond what could be, at least until 09/11, considered America's worst nightmare.
summary: 'Parkland' - An Emotional Memory Of A National Tragedy

reviewText: If one wishes to see acting and editing of the highest caliber, Parkland is without comparison. The assassination of President Kennedy, like most historical events, is often seen as a story of significant characters--the President, Ms. Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson, Lee Harvey Oswald. But what about the other participants: the Secret Service agents, the FBI agents, the hospital workers, all involved in a horrific situation, where "Camelot," came to an end. Each of these people--whether great supporters of the President or not--become united in a harrowing event; each, in his or her own way, trying to deal with the unimaginable. The brother of Oswald damned by his brother 's actions; the Secret Service agents sullied by their inability to keep the President alive; the doctor--a resident--called upon to save "the most powerful man in the world."All of these hapless participants are inexorably tied to the tragedy. All of them are victims. The film is brilliantly directed, the acting superb, and the editing breathtaking. It is a difficult film to watch: you will reengage what you first felt when you learned that the President had been killed. As in all tragedies, there are moments of great compassion and great selfishness.This is a film about how we live and think. One that reminds us that, at any given moment, we may find ourselves in a situation of unimaginable complexity.
summary: Superb acting, editing---a film that celebrates, and adroitly, what happens when one is caught in the web of momentous events

reviewText: Each generation of Americans has its own special I-remember-where-I-was moment.  For my father's generation, it was the bombing of Pearl Harbor.  For the millennials, it was 9/11.  For many of us boomers, it was the assassination of JFK.  A very young teen at the time, those days left a tremendous impact upon me and helped shaped my life.  The 50th anniversary brought out a spate of new material, which I resisted.  I've already read lots of books, own lots of dvd's on the subject. After so much time, what new could be added?To be honest, I found this film in the Black Friday $1.96 bin at Walmart - otherwise, I would have let it pass me by. Even at that bargain price, I would have let it pass except that it included Paul Giamatti, Marcia Gay Harden and Billy Bob Thornton, among others.  Still skeptical, their presence gave it some gravitas. I finally watched it today and I must say it moved me tremendously.It does use some very familiar footage and news audio, but the film's strength is in the retelling of what happened in those trauma rooms at Parkland, what happened aboard Air Force One, what happened to Abraham Zapruder and what happened to some other players in this drama.  Most of the scenes depicting Parkland Hospital left me in tears - even after all of these years.  President Kennedy was in there for such a short time and until I saw this film, I really never even thought about what that time must have been like.In dealing with the Oswald family, the film used a great deal of kindness and sensitivity.  Even in the weeks after the assassination, Marguerite Oswald seemed as if some screws were loose; the filmmakers did reflect this characterization in their portrayal of her.  However, in the depiction of the the killer's brother, Robert, the filmmakers allow us to feel his pain and resignation.  The depiction of LH Oswald's burial is just as sad and lonely as likely it was.The always excellent Paul Giamatti's portrayal of Abraham Zapruder is particularly a stand-out. All of us Americans who were old enough to understand the meaning of what occurred in those days 50 years ago were thrust into such sadness immediately following the assassination.  For those like Mr. Zapruder who history tapped to play an unwitting part in those days, the burden seemed unbearable.  This is what Parkland demonstrates.Some events are just so big and still so unbelievable that every now and then, they need to be revisited, as if we still are looking for answers on whys and hows.  Parkland definitely gave more insights into some of the hows.  Those images will stay with me for a while.
summary: Like being given a window into November, 1963

Parkland is the name of the hospital that JFK - and later Lee Harvey Oswald - were taken to after they were shot.  The story goes beyond the events at the hospital however.The film begins the morning of November 22, 1963 in Fort Worth where the Kennedy's had spent the night at the Texas Hotel.  After a couple speeches, Kennedy makes the short flight to Dallas Love Field.  During this time we see the routine of the Parkland staff, the FBI, the Secret Service and Abraham Zapruder (Paul Giamatti).  Zapruder, of course shot the 8 mm film of the motorcade, before, during and after the shots were fired.The medical trauma at Parkland is filled with expected chaos, and frankly is a bit gruesome to watch.  But the filmmakers only show glimpses of JFK and Jackie, keeping a respectful distance.  Zapruder is stunned by the tragedy, Kennedy being a hero of his, but a nearby newsman reminds him of what he has on film.  While we expect the scenes at Parkland to be hectic, I didn't expect it to be the same as Zapruder and the Secret Service race around the city trying to get the film developed.  And then they had to go somewhere else to get copies made.One of the more effective side-stories, and one rarely mentioned, has to do with Oswald's brother Robert (James Badge Dale) and their loony mother, Marguerite (Jacki Weaver).  Back at Parkland, confusion continues as the Dallas County Medical Examiner insists Kennedy's body not be removed in accordance with state law.  The new President Johnson would not leave without Jackie and JFK's body.  Living in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, we were exposed more than most, to numerous anecdotes and stories surround the fateful day and those that followed.  So we are familiar with the story of Oswald's burial.  Having no pall bearers on hand, Robert asked the few reporters/photographers to help move the casket.  I think that's the first time I've seen that in a film or documentary."Parkland" sticks with the facts, including some more recently discovered (the FBI awareness of Oswald), and doesn't play loose with conspiracy theories.  It is an excellent dramatic re-creation of those sad days from a somewhat different perspective.The Blu ray transfer is excellent.  It comes in 1080p resolution with a 1.78:1 aspect ratio.  It includes Spanish and English SDH subtitles.  The video looks great with proper color tones and detail.  Shot digitally with many scenes done with hand-held cameras, the movie still looks film-like.  I saw no digital artifacts.  The audio comes in Dolby TrueHD 5.1.  This lossless soundtrack is as good as the video.  The surrounds are often in use but in a natural way.  The confusion and chaos in the hospital for example.  The dialog is very clear and natural.  Extras are minimal.  There is a commentary with director Peter Landesman, some deleted scenes and that's it.  Well, there are some Millennium Entertainment previews.
summary: (BLU RAY REVIEW) An fine overlooked film of JFK's assassination

reviewText: "Parkland" (2013 release; 93 min.) brings the story of the events surrounding John F. Kennedy's assassination in Dallas on November 22, 1963. The movie doesn't waste any time and in the initial scenes we get to briefly meet the various players who'd become intimately involved in the events of that day: the Secret Service guys, the FBI guys, the accidental witnesses to the assassination, the doctors and nurses at Parkland Memorial Hospital, and of course the President and his immediate entourage. The initial 15 min. or so of the movie make ample use of the archive footage that exists from JFK's visit to Forth Worth and Dallas. After being shot, the President is taken to Parkland, where a young doctor (played by Zac Efron) at first is overwhelmed with the task at hand, and then gives his all in trying to save the President's life. A couple of major story lines eventually emerge: Abraham Zapruder (played by Paul Giamatti) films the entire sequence of events with his new 8 mm camera, and quickly gets inundated by the media to get that footage; even more interesting for me is the story line involving Robert Oswald, brother of Lee Harvey, dealing with the fall-out of being associated with/family of the killer of the US President.Couple of comments: next month marks the 50th commemoration of JFK's assassination and while we all know pretty much what happens, this movie does shed some interesting perspectives on what happened immediately after the assassination, including at Parkland. Other than the (sporadic) scenes with Zac Efron, Paul Giamatti or Billy Bob Thornton (as the head of the Dallas Secret Service), the cast is made up of unknowns (for me anyway), and that plays out very well as it gives a more authentic feel to the movie. The use of the historic footage adds as well (at some point, one of the TV reporters (Sam Donaldson perhaps?) sums up that fateful day as "too much, too ugly, and too fast" and how true that is. It may very well be that America lost its innocence that day.Imagine my surprise when out of the blue and without any pre-release hype or advertising this movie showed up this week at my local art-house theatre here in Cincinnati. I figure this will not play very long and went to see it right away. The screening I saw this at tonight was not very well attended (all of 3 people, including myself), so that is not a good sign, which is a shame as I think this movie deserves an audience. Bottom line: if you are one of those who still is interested in the terrible events that took place in Dallas in late November, 1963, I would encourage you to check out "Parkland", be it in the theatre or on DVD/Blu-ray.
summary: Front row seat to US history: "Too much, too ugly, too fast"

reviewText: I had been checking the listings of local theaters looking to find a showing of PARKLAND and instead surprisingly found the DVD of this in a bin at Rite Aid.  Now I know why I found it there instead of at the local movie multiplex.The movie begins by interspersing intros to some of the major players in what is to follow with newsreel footage of the real Kennedy arriving in Texas and riding to death and destiny in Dallas. Then comes the Hollywood stuff with a very poorly done recreation of the moment Paul "Zapruder" Giametti enters the pages of history via his Bell & Howell. Despite intercutting footage of the actual goings-on in Dealy Plaza on that day, the only actors in this recreation are those playing Zapruder and his receptionist.  This scene signals the restricted, low-budget seeming style of the rest of the movie - which seems much more of a TV movie than one geared for theatrical release.  Perhaps this is one reason it didn't go far on the big screen.  Anyway, soon after we have Zac Efron as Dr. Charles 'Jim' Carrico.  Zac Efron doesn't look at all like he is from 1963, not with his very contemporary three-day growth.  Couldn't the actor have shaved before the cameras rolled?  Anyway, where in all the scenes at Parkland is Governor Connally?  Where are the doctors voicing any of their findings with regards to the wounds on the President?  The throat wound was thought to be an entry wound by the majority of the doctors at Parkland.  Where in the film is the sudden magic appearance of the magic bullet on the mystery stretcher?  Where is Bobby Kennedy? Where is Jack Ruby? Why is Oswald virtually a phantom throughout the entire film - with one of the best scenes dealing with him amongst the deleted scene extras?  Why does the film lead a viewer to believe it a fact that Oswald wrote a note saying he would blow up the FBI building?  The actual note was destroyed by its recipient, agent James Hosty. Hosty himself later never said that the blowing up of the office was mentioned in the Oswald letter - yet this factoid is presented as fact in the film.  Curiously, if one just came in on the last fifteen minutes or so, the film seems more an ode to Oswald than an homage to Kennedy.  Cross-cutting between the lonely lowering of Oswald's casket accompanied by sombre dirge-like music and Hosty's burning crucial, critical FBI reports on Oswald while hiding out in a bathroom just makes one feel like the Truth about the supposed sniper is being buried and burned simultaneously.  Though based on the book by Warren Report believer Bugliosi, these final scenes seem instead to truly, silently question the Warren Report's rush to judgement.Anyway, as a film about an overwhelmingly seismic moment in American history it is extremely tepid. The only real-seeming moment in the entire dull undertaking is when the Parkland doctors clash with the secret service about the removal of Kennedy's corpse from Parkland to DC. And Jacki Weaver as Oswald's Mom sticks out like a sore thumb while Jeremy Strong as her enigmatic son is the best actor in the movie.  Trouble is, blink and you'll miss him!  Anyway, bottom line...the film is a flatline.

reviewText: This is a film about the known events of the day Kennedy was shot and the days that followed. It uses film footage from the era as well. The movie centers on three lives: Abraham Zapruder (Paul Giamatti) who shot the famous film; Robert Oswald (James Badge Dale) Lee Harvy's (Jeremy Strong) brother; and Dr. Charles 'Jim' Carrico (Zac Efron) the one guy of the three who worked at Parkland Hospital.The film doesn't add anything new to the discussion. It is a well made docu-drama, but as someone too familiar with the events and people involved, I found it on the boring side. The film included scenes such as getting the film developed, cleaning up the aftermath of the hospital, and removing seats from Air Force One.  A younger generation who only know the event from history books might find the film more interesting and entertaining.Too little, too slow, too boring.
